importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The research voyage by CSIRO scientists in late 2022 marked the beginning of the discovery of new deep-sea species in the Gascoyne Marine Park.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The depth range of discovery (122m to over 600m) highlights the extreme conditions and unexplored depths of the ocean where new species are found.

keyTakeAways: A semi-transparent crab about the size of an almond and a tiny glowing lantern shark have been discovered in the deep sea off Western Australia.
The West Australian Lantern Shark, up to 40cm long, has large eyes and bioluminescence from photophores on its belly and flanks, discovered more than 600m below sea level.
A new type of porcelain crab, about 1.5cm in length, uses long hairs to catch plankton instead of claws, found at around 122m depth.
These discoveries are part of a broader effort by Australian scientists to explore uncharted marine areas in the Gascoyne Marine Park.
Australia, a global biodiversity hotspot with over a million species, still has vast portions of its ocean unexplored, leading to ongoing discoveries.
The research voyage in 2022 uncovered approximately 20 new species, with scientists estimating up to 600 more yet to be described and named due to time-intensive verification processes.

namedEntities.name: Australia
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A country and biodiversity hotspot known for its rich and unique marine and terrestrial species.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Australia's status as a global biodiversity hotspot makes it a critical location for discovering new species, especially in unexplored marine regions.

namedEntities.name: CSIRO
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Australia's national science agency responsible for conducting scientific research and exploration.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: CSIRO led the deep-sea research expedition in 2022, which directly resulted in the discovery of multiple new species.

namedEntities.name: Gascoyne Marine Park
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A marine protected area located about 20km off the coast of Western Australia.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The research voyage took place in this area, where unexplored deep-sea habitats led to the identification of new species.

namedEntities.name: West Australian Lantern Shark
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A newly described deep-sea shark species found over 600m below sea level with bioluminescent features.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This species is one of the two new species discovered during the expedition and is notable for its glowing belly and large eyes adapted to deep-sea conditions.

namedEntities.name: Porcelain crab
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A new type of porcelain crab, about 1.5cm long, found at 122m depth and feeding using long hairs instead of claws.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This species exemplifies a unique feeding behavior and adaptation found in deep-sea environments, contributing to understanding of marine biodiversity.

namedEntities.name: Carnavon Flapjack Octopus
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A newly discovered small octopus species, about 4cm in size and rusty red in color.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is one of the 20 new species identified during the 2022 expedition, adding to the diversity of marine life found in deep-sea regions.

namedEntities.name: Western Australian Museum
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A scientific institution that houses and studies aquatic zoology collections.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Dr. Andrew Hosie, a curator there, provided expert insight into the feeding behavior of the porcelain crab.

namedEntities.name: Dr. Will White
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A fish scientist at CSIRO who explained the bioluminescent properties of lantern sharks.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He provided scientific context about the bioluminescent nature of the lantern shark, a key feature in understanding its biology.

namedEntities.name: Dr. Andrew Hosie
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A curator of aquatic zoology at the Western Australian Museum.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He contributed scientific explanation of the porcelain crab's feeding mechanism, highlighting its unique adaptation.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Australian scientists from CSIRO, during a 2022 deep-sea research expedition in the Gascoyne Marine Park off Western Australia, discovered two new species: a semi-transparent porcelain crab about 1.5cm long found at 122m depth, and a glowing West Australian Lantern Shark up to 40cm long discovered over 600m below sea level. These discoveries are part of Australia’s ongoing efforts to explore its vast, uncharted marine environments—known for their unique biodiversity. The findings highlight the importance of deep-sea exploration and underscore that despite Australia's status as a global biodiversity hotspot, thousands of species remain unknown. Scientists estimate up to 600 more species may still be described due to the lengthy process of verification and classification.
title: Australia: Almond-sized crab and tiny lantern shark discovered in deep seas
